text:
- Hi, I'm Anna Green, Head
of Small and Medium Business

here at AWS across Asia,
Pacific, and Japan.
I'm really excited to welcome Jason Grant,

the Head of IT at Rubicon
Water to speak to us today

at our Business Builders
Series here at AWS.
Jason, welcome.

I am so pleased to be talking
to you today about water,
our world's most precious resource.

Can you tell us a bit about
Rubicon's purpose and vision,

and really kind of frame
the conversation for us

in terms of what it is
you're trying to build?
- Yes, I can, Anna,
So, thank you.

And we're certainly in the
sustainability business
so you've come to the right place.
So to give you three sobering statistics
just to frame everybody's challenge,
the OECD predicted that by the year 2050,
around 40% of the world's population

are gonna be experiencing
severe water scarcity,

two thirds of the fresh
water used on the planet
goes to agricultural purposes
with possibly 50% or more that being lost
due to clumsy delivery,
and then NASA reporting big problems
with our underground aquifers as well.

Now, all of this requires
intervention to get better,
and that's where Rubicon comes in.

So Rubicon offer devices
that regulate flow

down big canal systems and
onto farms and within farms.

We have the software to
orchestrate that delivery

and we have radio systems
that allow the communications.

What we've done so far is
shipped around 35,000 devices

around the planet, 17
countries and counting,
now shipping solutions in India as well,
and farmers are now seeing water
for the first time in 30 years.
So we can make a big difference here
to sustainability of food on the planet.

- That is such a cool story
about the use of technology
in helping to create sustainable outcomes.

I'm really interested
to hear more from you
about what the role of software is
in improving water productivity.

- Okay, well, I'll open
by giving you two stories

that illustrate the benefits
that software is making.

So one customer we have
in the USA, for example,

were losing quite a lot of
water on a regular basis.

So if you think about an
Olympic swimming pool,
and maybe stack seven of those,

seven and a half of those
up to make a big skyscraper

out of water, maybe a
question for you, Anna

is how frequently do you
think they were losing
that amount of water?
- Well, I used to use the swimming pool,

the local pool as a child,
maybe every three months.

- Well, would you believe
they were losing it every day?

And then there are other
irrigational authorities like them

around the planet who
are doing the same thing,
so that's kind of bad, right?
Then we've got a customer in Australia
who's recently announced

that they're giving back
300 million worth of water

or potentially just banking
it for drought planning.
So you can see

that there's a big
commercial proposition there,

and also there's the
environmental benefit as well.

We think that we're
making a huge difference
in the area of sustainability.
- Totally sounds like you are.
And look for us here at AWS.
We really focus on trying to offload

the undifferentiated heavy
lifting for our customers
so they can get on with a business
of actually doing business.
Can you tell us about

how your team are looking
at using technology

so that they can focus on
the sustainable outcome
versus, you know the infrastructure stack?
- Yeah, totally.

And that's super important
to me as a development lead.

We've got customers who
are naturally rural,

don't have the capacity to
maintain on-prem solutions,

so they're increasingly asking
us to host our solutions
in AWS.
And then we've got SAS solutions too,
with a great economy of scale proposition.

As the dev lead, I can now
do my continuous delivery,

and allows me to concentrate
on my features and my product,

rather than maintaining all
of these different customers.

Now, how does that help
with sustainability?
Well, firstly, the proximity is important,

allows me to go to all
corners of the planet,

and we've got regulatory
constraints sometimes

so we have to have the data
within national boundaries.
AWS helps me to do that.

Also that economy of scale
that I was talking about
allows me to push into economies

where the costs might have
otherwise been a barrier.
- I love that.

It's so great to hear that
our technology is helping you
to scale, I guess, fundamentally
and think about different markets.
So can you tell us more

about what's next for
Rubicon in the future?
- We wanna partner with those entities
who care about water delivery,

so we want to get water to
the right place efficiently

and make every last drop
get to the right place
in terms of crop vitality.
The other thing we want to do
is hit the bottom of the pyramid

and make sure we get out
to diverse locations,

arid locations, make sure that
we hit emerging economies,
and if we do that,

we could potentially benefit
millions around the world.
- Thank you so much, Jason.

That is such an amazing
story of using technology

to really deliver great
outcomes for communities
across the world.

So I just wanna say thank
you so much on behalf of AWS

for joining me for this
conversation today.
- And thank you, Anna and AWS.
It's been a pleasure.
